awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Program in Climate and Space Science Observation (PICASSO) at the University of Michigan
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor will provide seven students, annually, with a hands-on exposure to this hybrid (observation, modeling) approach to scientific investigation.   These students will have the opportunity to: (a) design and carry out a mentor-guided research project, (b) participate in a series of professional development activities, (c) develop skills in communicating science and research results to their peers and the general public, (d) learn from faculty and graduate students about the nuances of selecting, applying to, and succeeding in graduate school, and (e) develop a better overall understanding of the many facets of a career in STEM fields.  Students will present their research results at an end of summer symposium, and will receive financial support to attend and present their work at a professional conference following the completion of the summer program. 

This REU site will seek to engage students from groups typically underrepresented in STEM disciplines in research from a broad range of atmospheric and space science disciplines, including climate science and adaptation planning, atmosphere-biosphere interactions, aerosols and atmospheric chemistry, air quality, space-based remote sensing, space-weather and planetary atmospheres. Improvements in our understanding of the atmospheric and space sciences rely on the use of both ground- and space-based observations.  In addition to providing insights into many complex environmental processes and trends, these observations can also be used to evaluate the performance of regional/global climate models, ecosystem-level models, and space weather models, each of which represent our best theoretical descriptions of these processes.  These observations and models are used to protect human health and welfare in a number of ways, ranging from aiding in the development of adaptation strategies to protect community infrastructure in a changing climate, to allowing for the prediction of the timing and intensity of solar storm interactions with our atmosphere, which have the potential to impact communications and our nation's power grid.  Through the introduction of the students to topics such as measurement design, quality assurance and control, data analysis and presentation, model development and evaluation, and assessment and communication of scientific uncertainties, this project will seek to produce scientifically and ethically responsible future scientists, while improving the overall self-efficacy of these students regarding their continued participation in STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site was hosted within the University of Michigan's Department of Climate and Space Sciences and Engineering.  The overall objectives of the Program in Climate and Space Science Observation (PICASSO) site program included: (1) engagement of a diverse cohort of undergraduate students in faculty-mentored research projects related to the climate and space sciences, (2) development of students' self- efficacy with respect to participation in research and careers in STEM fields, (3) development of scientific communication skills (both oral and written) with which to convey their findings and experiences working in STEM fields, and (4) development of culturally, societally and ethically competent scientists and engineers.

With respect to Objective (1), PICASSO hosted 23 participants over the three year period covered in this report (2018-2020), each of whom worked on a faculty-mentor-led research project.  These projects included mentoring from graduate students and post-doctoral fellows within the department, as well.  We believe that we met our objective of hosting a diverse cohort of students, as of these 23 participants, 10 identified as male, 11 identified as female and two  identified as LGBTQIA+.   Additionally, 14 participants identified as caucasian, four as Hispanic/Latinx, three as African American, one as Native American and one as multiracial.  Our program has worked to create an inclusive community for these students, through the careful planning of program-related science, professional and social activities.  With respect to Objective (2), our faculty mentors were encouraged to allow the program participants to share in the development of the scope and timelines associated with their projects.  Comparison in pre- and post-program evaluations have shown growth in our participant's perceptions of their understanding of/confidence in research skills and STEM careers, including increased awareness with respect to the process of applying to graduate schools. With respect to Objective (3), our participants were provided with a number of workshops related to technical communication.  These workshops included approaches to writing/reviewing scientific manuscripts, and the design and presentation of scientific posters.  The students took part in an End of Program Poster Fair, which allowed them to practice the communication of their research results by sharing their work with department faculty, students and staff.  Additionally, our participants were provided with funding to attend a scientific conference of their choice (Examples: Annual Meeting of the American Meteorological Society and the Fall Meeting of the American Geophysical Union) to share their work with the broader scientific community and to expand their scientific network.  With respect to Objective (4), our students participated in workshops related to ethics and the responsible conduct of research.  Additionally, our students learned about the importance of giving back to the local community through their participation in a series of community service activities, including local food distribution to those in need, as well as serving as panelists for a University of MIchigan Center for Engineering Diversity & Outreach summer program for underrepresented high school students.

Research outcomes were disseminated through annual technical reports, the REU website, and the aforementioned poster presentations at the site program's End-of-Program Poster Fair and other scientific meetings.
